comment_message: Such a coincidence there was also a technical error on Wednesday, where the O Level English Listening Comprehension was broadcasted over Symphony 92.4 FM.
The planner for the exams should be reprimanded or replaced for inconsistencies that cannot be tolerated!

Hi Kenny and Yeon Ja, thanks for bringing this up. We're aware of the technical glitch during the GCE Listening Comprehension. It happened at the start of the broadcast for 17 seconds and the rest of the 45-min examination continued smoothly. At its conclusion, Symphony 92.4FM repeated the affected passage so that students could listen to it again. We'd like to apologize again for the technical issues on radio this week and we sincerely hope to seek your kind understanding on this matter.

Dr Lee said such opportunities to unite the nation should not be left to commercial decisions, and that the relevant bodies, cable TV operators and telcos should pool resources and prepare for the negotiations ahead of time.

Replying to this, Ms Fu said that while the Government does provide funding support to help with escalating fees for broadcast, it would be "unwise" for the government to underwrite any amount demanded by rights owners and insist on having live telecasts regardless of cost.

She added that this would be a poor position to take particularly while rights are being negotiated.

Dear Su-Ana. We would like to clarify that we did not delete your earlier post where you highlighted the glitch on a Suria programme. On occasions, viewers have taken the same route as you alerting us on TV glitches they experienced. We appreciate them for taking the time and effort in informing us so that we can troubleshoot and prevent future occurrences. 

And on the glitch that appeared on Suria, we are glad to hear that it was resolved very soon after. We would like to apologise for the technical glitch that affected your viewing pleasure.

In future, should you wish to contact Suria, you can visit ther facebook page https://www.facebook.com/MediacorpSuria/  or email them at  tellsuria@mediacorp.com.sg. Should you with to contact Mediacorp, you can drop us a message here on facebook or you can write an email to tellmediacorp@mediacorp.com.sg.

Reflecting back, 10 years ago, I was an avid EPL fan. Followed almost every games that was telecasted live, and it could be as many as 5 games over 1 weekend. I was passionate!
Then competition set in between the telcos and prices shot up. I decided to stop the subscription in protest. Initially, I suffered from withdrawal syndrome, trying hard to look for free to air channels over the net, and still followed the results closely every weekend.
Slowly, my passion dimmed a little by little. Started with too lazy to look out for free channel in the web, just reading the results over the weekend. Then as I slept early, and have new found hobby, i had totally weaned myself off soccer to the extend.... Who won the European Cup? 
My children dont watch soccer too, because i dont subscribe anymore. Somehow, sport bodies need to realise, this thing about profitability cannot carry on at such exorbitant rate. The support base will get smaller and passion will die.

Hi Kartik,

Thank you for your feedback on our broadcast of Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom. 

The programme was prepared for broadcast with a general audience in mind, where strong scenes like the knifing of a python and the eating of live snakes and monkey brains may be deemed inappropriate for some of our more sensitive viewers watching the movie.

Nonetheless, we value your views, and shall explore the possibility of relying more on consumer warning advisories so as to preserve such graphic depictions in our programmes.

We appreciate your comments and the opportunity to clarify.

If it's too sensitive then movies such as this should not be aired at all. What's the point of airing these movies with elements which make the movie memorable taken out? Like what you had stated in your reply above, I warning would be appropriate so that sensitive viewers could choose not to watch at all, this would be more logical solution rather than having a blanket ban on everything. 

Furthermore, I believe similar scenes can be viewed in channels such as Nat Geo. So I think what you are doing is just overkill. You have to understand the fact that there are other viewers also, rather than the only the sensitive types so a one-size-fits-all approach does not work here. 

Considering the number of awards you have won as broadcaster of the year etc... I was under the impression of you knowing the needs of your audience. I hope changes can be made.

Hi Harry,

We refer to The Vales commercial on Channel 5, specifically the strong interest surrounding the advertisement being in Mandarin. 

While Channel 5, from a programming perspective, is positioned as an English language platform, current guidelines on commercials carried on the channel however, bear little restrictions on language. 

However, as audience inclusiveness and mass exposure of the commercials strongly benefit both viewers and the advertisers, Mediacorp will look into engaging with our advertorial clients to consider creative opportunities to make our non-English language commercials accessible to everyone.

We are very grateful for the candid feedback, and appreciate the opportunity to bring clarity on the matter.
Errrr, so that means that an EC like Vales is only meant for the Chinese speaking community in Singapore ?
Your message clarifies NOTHING, but continues to reinforce the discrimination against minorities in AN ENGLISH LANGUAGE CHANNEL, which should be in English.

Amazing that a national channel can behave in such an irresponsible manner ... the Vales is an EC (HDB ... public housing not private housing ... get it ??!!) meant for all races, not just the Chinese speaking right ???

If it was done in the Chinese channel, sure, it makes sense to be in Chinese. But a PUBLIC housing project advertised in the English channel in only the Chinese language reeks of discrimination, right ?? And how can you give me such a moronic reply as what you have posted ??
$$$$$$ takes precedence over everything else, I guess ??

Hi Harry, thank you for your replies. As mentioned, the current guidelines on commercials carried on the channel bear little restrictions on language. We have taken your feedback into consideration and will work with our advertorial clients to enable non-English language commercials be made accessible to everyone.

With your non-commital reply and with no clear indications to stop this discriminatory advertisement,  I will lodge a complaint against MediaCorp with the relevant government agencies. You people talk from just legal perceptive (that you are well covered) but your company has behaved irresponsibly in managing sensitivities from a race / language perspective ... Pretty disgusting attitude and behaviour from MediaCorp, if you ask me (and please do check with other minorities as well ... Almost all I talked to feel the same).

Hi, This animated series is a China production. The story is set in the 1930s after the Chinese Civil War and focuses on  the character Xiao Song and his auntie who sells pastries for a living. Through the depictions of Xiao Song's interactions with his classmates, villagers and fellow hawkers, the cartoon attempts to educate young viewers with good values of kindness, honesty, thriftiness, filial piety and more. The cartoon series is highly approved of by the authorities in China. It has won several awards in China and shown during prime-time on CCTV. 

With regard to the context of the scene, it would not have been possible to edit out the smoking character and still retain a meaningful flow and continuity of the story. 

The smoking character, though undesirable, is crucial as the story integrity is at stake, but it does not encourage or glamourise smoking. There was an educational point to the scene.  

At the same time, we do understand your point in the context of present day values and concerns. As such, we have a practice of editing out such scenes where possible, even in adult programmes. If not possible, we will recommend against buying such programmes if we have the opportunity to pre-vet a programme before purchase is made.  

For those who are interested in the context of the scene in the cartoon: 
A villager is brought before a police officer for suspected theft of a ginseng. The owner of a medicinal hall had been selling fake ginseng and the suspect had, in fact, stolen a carrot rather than ginseng. The owner of the medicinal hall is subsequently ordered by the police officer to pay for the medical treatment needed by the suspect's ailing son. The scene is crucial as it reveals the medicinal hall owner to be dishonest.

Hope this explanation, albeit lengthy, would provide a satisfactory answer to your concerns.

Letter to my MP:

I would like to ask you, as our MP, what you are doing to correct the obvious discrimination demonstrated by the Media Development Authority recently?

I refer to this embarrassing display of bigotry where a Singapore TV channel censored Obama's remarks on gay rights progress on the TV show Ellen.
TV viewers in Singapore and parts of Asia would not have heard the US President congratulate the openly lesbian TV host for her role in helping to change the attitudes of Americans towards LGBTI people.
The segment was cut entirely from the broadcast on Tuesday, February 23, on Channel 5.

Cutting out the President on topics like this does nothing to support societal values of equality and inclusivity. The MDA have failed in their duty and they need to be corrected.

Hi guys

An Ang Mo writing from Germany. 

I used to live in Singapore for four years and really loved it.  
In my oppinion Singapore is one of the best and most pleasant spots to live in the world. 

Everyone thinks that Germans are correct liable and always in time but Singaporeans are beating us in each of this point üòâ

While I was in Singapore I was forced to be an Expat wife üòâ.  
No work permit for gay civil partners.   That was very sad to realize  and was difficult to explain to my German friends. 
But I don't want to talk about the gay issue but about censorship. 

I had a lot of time to read and get to know Singapore a little better. 
One of the books was From Third world to First of Mr Lee. 
Since that I have the greatest respect of what he achieved for the little spot Singapore. 
Living together in a multicultural society provides many difficulties. 
In Germany there is a big discussion going on because of the refugee issue you might have heard of. 

When Mr Lee came in power 1965 Singapore was not just poor financially but also in education. 
That has changed dramatically in both ways. 
Singapore grew up. 

Here is my critics towards the current government.

I got to know the Singaporeans as very open self-conscious independent thinkers but also a little conservative. 

However in my oppinion the government treats the people still a little bit too much like children nowadays. 

The more educated Singaporeans get the more they find out about this fact.  It causes more and more questions about how they want to be treated. 

A monopolized media industry that censores is not showing the reality of the world.  The system treats its citizens like children need to be protected.

In times of Internet where everyone can see what really happens this causes more and more discontent. 

In my opinion this needs to be changed urgently because this is no longer appropriate.

I hope the Singapore government this will quickly see.

Sorry about my bad English.
Shut up, gay marriage is not approved in Germany. It is a terrible country with terrible human rights, like Singapore.

Why so angry?  
I never mentioned gay marriage.  
Do you have any frustration you want to talk about?

I wasn't very impressed by Australia either btw.  
I got hit by a police officer after gay Mardi Gras in Sydney and spent 120$ for a shitty party after. 

Greetings

Annie Tan  I don't think the POTUS and his wife were 'promoting homosexuality'. They were promoting tolerance (of homosexuality) : very different things. Just as people championing equal treatment / civil rights for racial minority such as Afro-Caribbeans (or equal rights for women) are NOT promoting Afro-Caribbean lifestyle/ culture or feminity. See what I mean?

Also I think you confuse any discussion of homosexual issues with pornography: otherwise why do you think children should not be exposed to what Barack and Michelle Obama said?

One last point: Statement like 'I have friends who are gay' does not give one cover from holding bigoted views/ prejudice. It's a ruse commonly used by demagogues. At present one could easily imagine Donald Trump saying 'I have Muslim / Mexican friends too' (He might already have said it!) In the bad old days white supremacist frequently used such (unproven) statement 'I have black friends too' to claim their lack of prejudice. Mark Rohan Pakianathan any thoughts?
I don't think it is about promoting this issue. It's more of rendering support and compassion to those who are part of the LGBT community. Nothing wrong with that.

Fong  I totally agree with your sentiments  - as a boy who spent the ages of 12 to 16 in Singapore, my experience of growing up gay over 30 years ago in Singaporean society was pretty traumatising in retrospect- people like me were invisible and the attitudes of most towards homosexuality were hostile. At one level it was a very lonely and isolating time and a period of inauthenticity. I didn't deserve that. Openness and positive LGBT role models in the media have a net healthy effect on society. It's great to see such different attitudes on most of the responses in the feed - perhaps the censors are out of step with the more open attitudes of Singaporean society. The people who are being harmed today are those lonely isolated LGBT children  - 30 years on I know they definitely deserve better. These kids are your brother , sister , cousin, pupil, friend .... They aren't a toxic enemy but human beings that need acceptance, love and  to know they are not alone.

Annie Tan I recommend reading up on 'internalised heterosexism' or 'internalised homophobia' It may help shed light on gut reactions. It is a rite of passage for most lesbian and gay people...I hope it brings you to a place of compasion and  self acceptance. Good luck x

Sometimes, a proper apology forthcoming is the better way to deal with this. The creative community holds high hopes that the media company such as Mediacorp and Singapore Press Holdings should assigned the right credit to the proper owner.

Yew Shinn Lim As a general guide, we may suggest the following. However, do provide your contact number for our Engineer to contact you for further analysis. 

Check your antenna and receiver connections

Check that the UHF antenna is connected to the antenna input of your digital receiver. If you are using an active antenna, make sure that the antenna power supply is available. Refer to the owner's manuals of your antenna and receiver if you are unsure of the proper connections.  

Adjust your antenna, if needed

Placing the indoor antennas on top or at the side of the TV may not be the best location. If you have trouble with digital TV reception, please try moving the antenna: 

Near a window, away from area whereby the signal may be block 
Position the antenna higher 
Away from other electronic equipment such as computers, DVD players, the HDMI cable and the television itself

Hi Bernard, due to the massive technical challenges that MediaCorp face in the path towards full digital broadcasting, we are staggering the planned HD roll-out in stages so as to better monitor and resolve any issues promptly while delivering the best digital signal across Singapore. Please visit our Digital TV micro-site at MediaCorp.sg/digitaltv for more details. On the move to broadcast 24/7 for these channels, we are currently exploring the feasibility given our limited resources. Please watch this space for more information and do continue to support MediaCorp channels.

Thank you for your reply. I am sure viewers are eagerly looking forward to 24/7 broadcasts for the MediaCorp channels that are not yet doing so. I hope this happens very soon. There are plenty of programmes available in Mandarin, Malay and Tamil. Programmes like "First Look Asia" can easily be broadcast in Malay and Tamil in the mornings. Furthermore, "live" chat programmes like "First Look Asia" should be broadcasting on weekends as well. I appreciate the technical challenges MediaCorp faces as it strives to achieve the best quality digital signals across the island. It would definitely be appreciated if the HD broadcasts for the channels I mentioned could be brought forward.

Coming to a foreign place always is a tough experience. Adjusting your lifestyle to integrate with societal norms that are pronouncedly different, is a great challenge. Somebody has to guide you through daily life aspects, to show you the intricate details of how a society operates,  to instill you the norms and values that make you a part of a new community.

This is what the TODAY newsletter has done for me. Giving me the important touch of Singaporeans daily life, making me able to get in touch with their aspirations, worries, interests, thoughts and dreams, has helped me tremendoysly to understand and admire Singapores great society.

Regarding the issue, Channel 5 was scheduled to carry the Barclays Singapore Open and the FINA/ARENA Swimming World Cup yesterday.

As the Barclays Singapore Open over ran by some 2 hours and Channel 5 was pre-committed to broadcast FINA/ARENA Swimming World Cup LIVE at 6pm, it was unfortunately not able to broadcast the final moments of Barclays Singapore Open. Updated results and the playoff between winner Italian Matteo Manassero and South African Louis Oosthuizen was shown later during News 5 Tonight and replayed at 12am.

I failed everything in this year's SA1 exams and i'm spending the whole june holidays studying from chapter 1 of each subject. I study 9 hours a day on the 3rd floor of my house with nothing to accompany me but an ipod, earphones, some energy bars and an old radio. Those old radios from the 1980s. On the first day of my revision, I was bored after a few hours and decided to turn on that radio. I switched the radio channel to 987FM and its was playing payphone. I started to listen and kinda got hooked to the song. I was surprised myself. I'd normally listen to hard rock and heavy metal but I love other kinds of emotional music, lyrics and all....so anyway, back to the topic. Mediacorp has changed my life by entertaining me and giving me a great laugh when i'm down. I love listening to 987FM's 'The Men Show' on Sunday afternoons and 'Music with Divian and Jaqcui' at night. Well.....I can say that mediacorp has been there for me, in a way. (:

I remember! I remember! I won 2 boxes of macadamia nut chocolates when I use to listen to the kids show on Saturday mornings. I took part in a contest and won the prize! Who knew I'd be working for the station that I won the prize from? Of course then it was Radio 1. =)

In far away London, thank goodness for internet radio, the 933 that I been listening to since kindergarden in my parents car is there for me at night.

Not to mention at 10/11pm here you suddenly hear the national anthem. I think I hear the national anthem here more than the time after I left JC!

When exams are nearing, I have been under million tons of stress, as usual. But when i knew 987, my favourite radio station, was on 'MeRadio', I downloaded the app on my phone and listened to it almost everyday. now, i dont just listen to it when i'm stressed! Almost everyday when i do my homework, I still listened to it! Thank you Mediacorp! :) <3

My beloved wife Constance Beck went home to Jesus 87 days ago - we have no children and I have been left more or less alone since that fateful day when part of me also died. I dare say that radio has been a small source of consolation during all this time. She enjoyed listening to 92.4 in the evenings and as she was going to sleep in her last days and I enjoy listening to both 92.4 and 90.5 during the days and evenings - it helps fill the silence of the days and nights which is now so empty without her and brings back memories of the music we loved and shared.   Thanks Mediacorp.

Anthony Chew We're so sorry for your loss. We're glad and moved to know that we have provided some small measure comfort. Thank you so much for sharing this deeply personal and moving moment with us, on behalf of the  Symphony 92.4FM and Gold90.5 FM families.
Someone to help us feel, someone to keep us involved...
@Anthony, my deepest sympathies on your loss.  Constance must have been a beautiful person ! Take care, stay strong and God Bless !!

Our family is always tuned in to Gold90.  Radio is on throughout the whole day.  

2 years ago, my son (then 3yo) was hospitalised for a very high fever.  He went into a fever fit and was hospitalised for 5 days.  It was really trying and heartbreaking for us as parents to see him on drips, constantly taking meds, sponging him day and night, waiting for results, sleepless nights etc.  It was so physically and emotionally draining.  

I am thankful that Gold was always with us throughout the hospital stay.  My phone was tuned into Gold.  That provided some entertainment and joy to us as we ploughed through the ordeal.  The DJs and the songs made us feel happier and helped preserve our sanity! :) 

During one of the nights after he was discharged, as my husband and I were lamenting about the huge bill and how exhausted we were, we were so blessed when we heard Tim Oh played one of our fav songs "Rainbow Connection".  It was our courtship song. :)  Just when we needed a jab to lift up our spirits, we got it from the radio! We just simply sat there and basked in the beautiful melody of the song.  The song refreshed our tired spirits and definitely brought smiles to our tired faces.  

Rainbows appear after stroms.  It is a beautiful sign that says 'Things are normal again'.  And yes, the worst of the storm was over.  Surely it was 'rainbow time' that followed.
All the best to to you Carol and your little "muppets" :)

Ameen Sayani presenting Binaca Geet Mala is my earliest memory from Radio. I think it was broadcast of Shortwave by Radio Ceylon. The whole family would tune in in the late 70's for the 1/2 hour show. The sound was barely audible with crackling being the predominant output! Yet memorable.

The RaRa show... I remember ah ter and his wife ms lala( played by Koh Chieng Mun) saying, "I don't know lah. He give me leh. I take lor..." when she was trying to teach someone singlish. I've since taught that same line to every foreigner who has asked me how to speak singlish.

I miss the local dramas,Triple Nine which starred James Lye & Wong Li Ling as well as Growing Up which starred Lim Kay Tong, Wee Soon Hui, Steven Lim, Andrew Seow, Irin Gan & Jamie Yeo. The other international show was the comedy, Mind Your Language. You know, Thousand Apologies, Oh Blind Me, Ah-So, Chairman Mao says, etc. :)
